chemotherapy.title: Common Chemotherapy Drugs
chemotherapy.description: Core cytotoxic agents used in leukemia and solid tumor regimens.

drugs.name: 6-Mercaptopurine
keyPoints: Give on an empty stomach; avoid milk products.
Monitor CBC and liver enzymes regularly.
Adjust dose for hepatic impairment.

drugs.name: Bleomycin
keyPoints: Monitor for pulmonary toxicity; perform baseline PFTs.
Observe for fever or chills after administration.
Avoid giving with high oxygen concentrations.

drugs.name: Busulfan
keyPoints: Monitor for bone marrow suppression.
Seizure prophylaxis may be required with high doses.
Check for pulmonary fibrosis with long-term use.

drugs.name: Cisplatin
keyPoints: Pre- and post-hydration essential to prevent nephrotoxicity.
Monitor renal function and electrolytes (Mg, K).
May cause ototoxicity—assess hearing regularly.

drugs.name: Cyclophosphamide
keyPoints: Hydrate patient before and after administration.
Monitor urine output; risk of hemorrhagic cystitis.
Use mesna for uroprotection if ordered.

drugs.name: Cytarabine (Ara-C)
keyPoints: Monitor for cerebellar toxicity—perform neuro checks.
May cause conjunctivitis—use prophylactic steroid eye drops.
High-dose regimens require leucovorin rescue.

drugs.name: Daunorubicin
keyPoints: Cardiotoxic—check baseline ejection fraction.
Use vesicant precautions; avoid extravasation.
Red-orange urine discoloration is expected.

drugs.name: Doxorubicin
keyPoints: Cardiotoxic—obtain baseline ECG and ejection fraction.
Avoid extravasation; use vesicant precautions.
Causes red discoloration of urine for 24–48 hrs.

drugs.name: Etoposide
keyPoints: Administer slowly to avoid hypotension.
Monitor CBC for bone marrow suppression.
Use infusion pump; avoid rapid bolus.

drugs.name: Ifosfamide
keyPoints: Always co-administer mesna for uroprotection.
Ensure aggressive hydration to prevent cystitis.
Monitor mental status—risk of CNS toxicity.

drugs.name: Methotrexate
keyPoints: Requires leucovorin (Calcium folinate) rescue for high doses.
Monitor renal function and maintain hydration.
Avoid NSAIDs and cotrimoxazole during therapy.

drugs.name: Vincristine
keyPoints: Fatal if given intrathecally.
Monitor for peripheral neuropathy and constipation.
Use warm compresses if extravasation suspected.

targetedTherapy.title: Common Targeted and Monoclonal Therapies
targetedTherapy.description: Targeted biologic and molecular agents used in cancer treatment.

drugs.name: Atezolizumab
keyPoints: Observe for fatigue, rash, or colitis symptoms.
Assess for hepatitis or endocrinopathies.
Do not restart after severe immune toxicity without physician review.

drugs.name: Bevacizumab
keyPoints: Monitor blood pressure regularly.
Assess for proteinuria before each cycle.
Delay surgery until wound healing is complete.

drugs.name: Bortezomib
keyPoints: Rotate injection sites to prevent local reactions.
Monitor for peripheral neuropathy.
Avoid intrathecal administration.

drugs.name: Cetuximab
keyPoints: Premedicate to prevent infusion reactions.
Monitor for acneiform rash—may indicate efficacy.
Use sunscreen; skin more sensitive to sunlight.

drugs.name: Imatinib
keyPoints: Take with food and a full glass of water.
Monitor for edema and liver function tests.
Assess CBC for cytopenias.

drugs.name: Nivolumab
keyPoints: Monitor for immune-related adverse events (colitis, hepatitis).
Assess thyroid and liver function regularly.
Interrupt therapy if severe autoimmune symptoms occur.

drugs.name: Pembrolizumab
keyPoints: Monitor for infusion reactions and immune toxicities.
Evaluate for cough or dyspnea—may indicate pneumonitis.
Delay doses if autoimmune toxicity suspected.

drugs.name: Rituximab
keyPoints: Premedicate with antihistamine and acetaminophen.
Monitor for infusion reactions—especially first dose.
Avoid live vaccines during and after treatment.

drugs.name: Sorafenib
keyPoints: Take on empty stomach (1 hr before or 2 hrs after meals).
Monitor for hand-foot skin reaction and hypertension.
Check liver function periodically.

drugs.name: Trastuzumab
keyPoints: Cardiotoxic—monitor LVEF before and during therapy.
Observe for infusion-related reactions.
Do not give concurrently with anthracyclines.

adjuvant.title: Adjuvant / Supportive Medications
adjuvant.description: Medications used to prevent or manage chemotherapy-related side effects and toxicities.

drugs.name: Allopurinol
keyPoints: Start before induction chemotherapy to prevent tumor lysis.
Encourage hydration and monitor uric acid levels.

drugs.name: Aprepitant
keyPoints: Used with 5-HT3 antagonist and steroid for highly emetogenic chemo.
May reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives.
Monitor for fatigue and hiccups.

drugs.name: Dexamethasone
keyPoints: Used for nausea prevention and as part of chemotherapy regimens.
Monitor blood sugar and signs of infection.

drugs.name: Filgrastim (G-CSF)
keyPoints: Monitor CBC; stop when ANC > 1000 in two consecutive days.

drugs.name: Furosemide
keyPoints: Used to maintain urine output during high-dose cisplatin or hydration protocols.
Monitor potassium and hydration status.
Record input/output balance accurately.

drugs.name: Leucovorin (Calcium Folinate)
keyPoints: Administer after high-dose methotrexate as rescue therapy.
Monitor methotrexate levels if available.
Do not confuse with folic acid (different indication).

drugs.name: Mesna
keyPoints: Always used with ifosfamide or high-dose cyclophosphamide.
Protects bladder from hemorrhagic cystitis.
Ensure hydration and monitor urine output.

drugs.name: Ondansetron
keyPoints: Administer 30 minutes before chemotherapy.
Monitor for headache and QT prolongation.

drugs.name: Palonosetron
keyPoints: Long-acting antiemetic—effective for delayed nausea.
Usually given once per cycle before chemotherapy.
Monitor for constipation and headache.

drugs.name: Pegfilgrastim
keyPoints: Administer at least 24 hours after chemotherapy.
Do not give within 14 days before next cycle.
Monitor for bone pain and WBC response.
